abstract.p: For the purpose of measuring µN- and mN-level micro-force, the optical reflection characteristics of a circular thin film are utilized to develop a micro-force sensor and double concentric circle fibres are used to measure the micro-force. This paper focuses on the relation between the output parameters of the system, namely the voltage ratio of the two receiving fibres, and the micro-force, the diameter, the thickness and the materials of the thin film, as well as the displacement between the fibre probe and the film. A measurement platform has been set-up and a large number of experiments have been conducted to determine the relationship between the voltage ratio and the micro-force, the diameter and the thickness of the thin film by using a least square exponential fitting algorithm. Furthermore, the errors between the calculating values from the fitting equation and the experimental values are obtained and analysed, which supports the conclusion that when the micro-force is in the range of 0–10 mN, the equation can be used to measure the micro-force with the resolution of 10 µN in the error range of −1.5%–+2.5%, and an automatic measurement process is realized.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently, measurement of micro-force, especially in the µN- and nN-level range, has been a research focus in many fields, such as biomedicine, cytology and microfabrication. Some researchers measured a micro-force and a pressure using optical fibre technology, and others used thin film technology to test a micro-force.

Measuring force methods using optical fibre technology include the micro-bend fibre method, the wavelength modulation fibre method, the photoelastic effect method, the phase modulation fibre method and the reflective fibre method (Huang, 2010). Lee et al. (2007) made use of the micro-bend fibre method to measure pressure. The fibre would bend under a pressure, which resulted in a partial light coupling from the fibre core in the cladding; this was followed with the loss of the optical power. Thus, the pressure applied on the fibre was measured according to the change of optical power. A fibre-optic pressure sensor was developed based on the intrinsic properties of a communication grade single-mode optical fibre (Zhao and Ansari, 2001). A self-referencing double interferometer was used for interrogation of the signal. The sensor was evaluated through measurement of the high pressures applied to the sand samples. The experimental results demonstrated the linearity of the system in the range 0–38.08 MPa, with a resolution of 0.03 MPa. Furthermore, a novel thin film pressure sensor based on fibre Bragg grating (FBG) was proposed (Zhichun et al., 2010), using FBG to measure the tangential strain of the disk-sensing film. The linear relationship between the FBG centre wavelength shift and pressure was determined. The pressure-sensing parameters of calibration were 14.6 pm/°C and 34.4 pm/kPa. Kulkarni et al. (2008) used inexpensive intensity-based plastic optical fibre (POF) in the form of a cantilever beam to monitor the force. The performance of the force sensor was evaluated during macro-bending caused because of the deflection of the beam by applied force. The experimentally obtained detector output of POF was in the range between 0.0098 and 19.613 N. The reproducibility of the sensor was observed in the limit of ±1%. Nobuhiro et al. (1997) presented a micro-force sensor with a force feedback method for scanning-force microscopy. The force sensor was constructed by using an optical fibre and a micro-cantilever. The facet of the optical fibre was coated with a gold thin film 15 Å thick. The deflection of the cantilever was measured by an interferometer consisting of the facet of the optical fibre and the cantilever surface. The force resolution of the system was 10−4µN with a bandwidth of dc ∼1 kHz.

Monitoring force sensors using thin film as a sensing element primarily depend on microelectromechanical system (MEMS) technology, including piezoresistive sensors, capacitive sensors, piezoelectric sensors and tunnelling effect sensors (Judy, 2001; Marinis, 2009). Generally, thin films used in transducers include lead zirconate titanate (PZT) film, ZnO thin film, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) thin film and Si-based film. Sun et al. (2005) developed a MEMS micro-force sensor with a novel configuration of differential tri-plate comb drives suitable for bulk micromachining. A high-yield fabrication process using DRIE (deep-reactive ion etching) on SOI (silicon-on-insulator) wafers was utilized to construct the high aspect ratio devices. The sensor had a high sensitivity of 1.35 µN/mV, good resolution of 0.68 µN and a large bandwidth of 7.8 kHz, which are required for characterizing the flight behaviour of fruit flies (Drosophila). Beyeler et al. (2009) and Lu et al. (2011) designed a six-axis MEMS force–torque sensor. A movable body was suspended by flexures that allow deflections and rotations along the x-, y- and z-axes. The orientation of this movable body was sensed by seven capacitors. Transverse sensing was used for all capacitors, resulting in a high sensitivity. Measurements showed that the resolution was of the order of a micro-Newton and nano-Newtonmetre. The standard deviation of the noise level of the capacitive readout corresponded to 1.4 µN and 3.6 mN·m, respectively, at a readout frequency of 30 Hz. Furthermore, very small piezoresistive force sensors of 200·200·640 µm2 (Meiss et al., 2011) were developed for a ‘HapCath’ system, which provides haptic feedback of the forces acting on a guide wire’s tip during vascular catheterization. The basic sensor performance was characterized, revealing a force resolution better than 1 mN, an overload resistance higher than 600 mN and a transfer characteristic from static to more than 1 MHz. Huang et al. (2009) presented a novel economical technique to fabricate hybrid silica/polymer optical fibre sensors that were capable of measuring large strain. The experimental set-up and the components were used in the fabrication process to realize the measurement of the strain. Moreover, the optical fibres are applied and researched in many other fields. For example, Zhang et al. (2000) developed an optical fibre sensor to measure particle concentration in water and Lyons and Lewis (2000) investigated the use of artificial neural networks in the enhancement of the performance of existing single-point sensors, two-dimensional and three-dimensional (3D) measurements and developments in multipoint sensors and sensor arrays.

This paper addresses measurement of µN- and mN-level force, utilizing the optical reflection characteristic of thin films and the optical fibre detection technology with a double concentric circle structure. The variations of the voltage ratio of luminous flux (VRLF) from two receiving fibres, as the output parameter of system, relating the micro-force, the diameter, the thickness of the thin film and the distance between the probe and the film, are investigated. In addition, three different materials of the thin film are chosen and a large number of experiments have been conducted on the system platform to obtain an equation relating the VRLF, the micro-force, the diameter and the thickness of the thin film.

sec.title: Transducer principle
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the fibre structure with a double concentric circle geometry. There are three bundles of fibres on one end, which includes one launching fibre (I0) and two receiving fibres (I1 and I2). On the other end, these three bundles of fibres construct a fibre probe with the structure of double concentric circles. The inner and outer rings of the probe are two receiving fibres (I1 and I2), and the middle ring is a launching fibre (I0), which are all packaged by the fibre cladding. In addition, the distance between the probe and the thin film is maintained at a certain value during the measurement process.

caption.p: Double concentric circle structure and the principle of the micro-force sensor.

sec.p: Double concentric circle fibre is a type of reflective optical fibre, as shown in Figure 1. Light from a light source enters into the launch fibre and irradiates the thin film through the fibre probe, and most of the light is reflected back to the probe by the surface of the thin film, because the thin film is a high-reflection film. The reflected light is received by two light-sensitive detectors though receiving fibres, and the two detectors transfer the luminous flux into voltage values. When an outside micro-force is applied at the centre of the circular film, it causes an isotropic deflection along the radial direction of the circular film and the luminous flux is changed consequently. Furthermore, if the loaded micro-force changes, the bending profile of the circular film changes and a different luminous flux is measured. Thus, we can measure the magnitude of the micro-force applied on the thin film by measuring the luminous flux from two receiving fibres.

Figure 2 shows the mechanism of optical intensity modulation. When F is equal to 0, the circular thin film does not deflect and the optical intensities of the two receiving fibres are the same, namely, I1 is equal to I2. When F is larger than 0, the circular thin film deflects under the positive force, which results in weakening the optical intensity in the inner fibre I1 and strengthening the optical intensity in the outer fibre I2. Thus, I1 is less than I2, which forms a differential output. Correspondingly, when F is less than 0, the circular thin film deflects under the negative force, which results in strengthening the optical intensity in the inner fibre I1 and weakening the optical intensity in the outer fibre I2. Thus, I1 is larger than I2, which forms a reverse differential output (He and Cai, 2007; Li and Zhang, 2005; Sastikumar et al., 2010). The signals received by detectors from the two receiving fibres are luminous flux Ф, but not the optical intensity I. So, the areas of the inner and outer rings should be considered because Ф is equal to the product of the optical intensity and the area. However, the luminous flux and the optical intensity will change when the voltage of the light source has any fluctuations, which will influence the precision and the repeatability of the measurement system using the luminous flux from one receiving fibre to reflect the applied micro-force. Thus, the ratio of luminous flux from the outer ring fibre and the inner ring fibre, Ф2/Ф1, is utilized to measure micro-force. Two detectors transfer the luminous flux from two receiving fibres into the voltages, respectively, so the VRLF

sec.title: Experimental platform
sec.p: A testing system composed of a 3D-motion platform, a particle clamping and loading module, an optical fibre and path module, and a photoelectric conversion and measurement module is constructed. The weights of particles are considered as different applied micro-forces in the experiments and calibrating process. The particle loading process includes four steps: (1) a gripper clamps the particle and places it on the particle stage; (2) the gripper moves to the centre of the circular thin film; (3) the gripper releases the particle on the centre of thin film; (4) the gripper returns back to the starting position and waits for the next instruction. The particle clamping and loading module is shown in Figure 3, and the motions of clamping and loading are realized by the relative motion of the gripper and a wedge-shaped block driven by a precision lead screw.

Figure 4 shows the experimental platform of the measurement system. The launching fibre connects with the light source, and the two receiving fibres are connected to a signal-processing box in which two photoelectric detectors and signal-filtering/amplifying circuits are placed. The luminous flux from the two receiving fibres are converted into voltages and introduced into the IPC (Industrial Personal Computer) by a data-acquisition card after filtering and amplifying. Furthermore, these experimental data also can be acquired by a DSP (Digital Signal Processor) using four equal-spaced sample methods (Vizireanu, 2009, 2011).

caption.p: Experimental platform of the measurement system.

sec.p: In an experimental process, a particle is placed on the particle stage and the data of the starting point and ending point are entered in the testing program. Furthermore, the acceleration/deceleration limits are set in the program, then the ‘Test’ button is clicked and an automatic test process is executed. The voltage values according to the luminous flux of two receiving fibres are recorded in the program and the VRLF is figured out after calculating.

In Section 4 of this paper, we derive an equation relating the VRLF, the micro-force, the diameter and the thickness of the thin film. If the known diameter and thickness of the thin film are entered in the testing program, by substituting the measured VRLF into the fitting equation, the micro-force will be displayed on the screen automatically, which is a whole testing process. In addition, the initial condition values, the VRLF and the micro-force are itemized into a database for an upcoming inquiry.

sec.title: Equation fitting

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This paper focuses on a thin film micro-force sensor at the mN level by using the double concentric circle optical fibre. The relations among the VRLF of two receiving fibres, the applied micro-force, the diameter and the thickness of the thin film were explored. The fitting equation about these four parameters was obtained to show the relations among them as follows.

list-item.p: The scale of the micro-force sensor is from 0 to 10 mN, and Equation (1) relating the VRLF, the micro-force, the diameter and the thickness of the thin film can be used to test the micro-force in the error range of −1.5%–+2.5%.
The VRLF decreases as the film thickness increases; the VRLF increases as the film diameter or the micro-force increases.

If the elastic modulus of the thin film is less, the VRLF varies more obviously. However, the bad linearity of high-pressure PE or CPP makes them unsuitable to be used as a sensitive element, and TPU is fit for the measurement system.

The larger the distance between the probe and the thin film, the more obviously the VRLF varies. However, the variation curve has bad linearity and does not satisfy the requirements of the measurement system when the distance is 20 mm. The distance of 8 mm is reasonable.
